questions.question_text: Which VPN connects the transport-side WAN Edge interface to the underlay/WAN network?

discussion.content: Agree with given answer.
vpn 0 correct
right answer

comments.content: A is correct. Directly from your link: "For example, ip-prefix 0.0.0.0/0 le 16 matches all IP prefixes with lengths from /1 through /16."

discussion.content:
This should be A.
• 0.0.0.0/0—Match any prefix–length pair.
• 0.0.0.0/0 le length—Match any IP prefix whose length is less than or equal to length. For example, ip-prefix 0.0.0.0/0 le 16 matches all IP prefixes with lengths from /1 through /16.
https://sdwan-docs.cisco.com/Product_Documentation/Software_Features/SD-WAN_Release_16.3/06Policy_Basics/03Localized_Control_Policy/Configuring_Localized_Control_Policy

Selected Answer: B
0.0.0.0/0 le 16 matches all IP prefixes with lengths from /0 to /16. The question asks for /1 to /16.
Option B is a ridiculous answer, as it only matches routes where the first bit is a 0.

comments.content: Why would you think that? You even said, "up to /16." So that does NOT include /17, /18, etc. That's what up to /16 means. The mask is not longer than /16.
Option B is a ridiculous answer, as it only matches routes where the first bit is a 0.

discussion.content:
Option A (0.0.0.0/0 le 16) also matches the criteria but it includes all IP prefixes up to /16, including those longer than /16 (e.g., /17, /18, etc.), which may not be desired.

B

Selected Answer: A
Correct answer is A.

This should be A as well.

• 0.0.0.0/0 le length—Match any IP prefix whose length is less than or equal to length. For example, ip-prefix 0.0.0.0/0 le 16 matches all IP prefixes with lengths from /1 through /16.

Reference: https://sdwan-docs.cisco.com/Product_Documentation/Software_Features/SD-WAN_Release_16.3/06Policy_Basics/03Localized_Control_Policy/Configuring_Localized_Control_Policy
Technically A is flawed becasue A match the default route 0.0.0.0/0, of which the prefix-length is arguably 0.

Selected Answer: A
Corretto A

B is correct.
le denotes any range between 0-16(inclusive)

comments.content: no, 0.0.0.0/1 le 16 does not match "all prefixes", the /1 tells to check the first bit of the network, thus NOT all prefixes.

discussion.content: A is correct of course, but 0.0.0.0/1 le 16 is also matching all prefixes from /1 to /16, so.. interesting..
A is correct
The question clearly says from /1 to /16, 0.0.0.0/0 match everything Broadcast addr is 255.255.255.255. 0.0.0.0/1 Broadcast addr is 127.255.255.255 dont get confused isnot the same. i would go with B

questions.question_text: An engineer is configuring a list that matches all IP prefixes with lengths from /1 to /16 in a centralized control policy. Which list accomplishes this task?

choices.E: Distribute crypto key information among WAN Edge routers.
choices.B: Configure and monitor WAN Edge routers.
choices.C: Distribute route and policy information via OMP.
choices.A: Authenticate and authorize WAN Edge routers.
choices.D: Distribute the IP address from DHCP server to WAN Edge routers.

questions.question_text: In the Cisco SD-WAN solution, vSmart controller is responsible for which two actions? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CE
thats all

Selected Answer: CE
Correct

Selected Answer: CE
Correct
it should be 'set service ...' and not 'site service ...' but otherwise B is correct

Notice the FW address and VPN id.

Correct answer is B

In order to forward traffic to Site ID 2 and to get filtered through the hub firewall
The VPN 10 service address needs to be defined 1.1.1.1 (system ip)
Also the control-policy firewall-service would need to forward traffic out of VPN 10
with a route-map to filter traffic.

Option B facilitates the request

B - this is pulled right from a policy config guide for v20.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/policies/vedge-20-x/policies-book/service-chaining.html

questions.question_text: An engineer is configuring a data policy for packets that must be captured through the policy. Which command accomplishes this task?

discussion.content:
C.
Actions - Whether to accept or reject (and drop) matching packets, and how to process matching packets.

Selected Answer: B
I believe is B, because the question is " packets that must be captured through the policy", my understand of the question is that a specific set of packets needs to be captured, and Match would be need it to define which packets will be captured

I believe its C as its clearly shown here

https://www.cisco.com/c/dam/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/config-18-4.pdf#page=358
In my optic, it is C.

The answer is C. 
Logging matching traffic will be under actions.

vSmart(config-sequence-number)# action (accept | drop) [count counter-name] [log] [tcp-optimization]

Selected Answer: B
capture the packet. Answer B

Selected Answer: C
How about log packets after the match condition is satisfied? It will come under C, right?
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/configuration/policies/vedge/policies-book/data-policies.html

Selected Answer: B
I would choose B because you always have the default action by default.

vSmart-1(config-vpn-list-1)# sequence 1
vSmart-1(config-sequence-1)# ?
Possible completions:
 action Accept or drop
 match Match criteria

Selected Answer: B
i looked at this from JTPRO https://www.ciscolive.com/c/dam/r/ciscolive/us/docs/2020/pdf/DGTL-BRKRST-2791.pdf#page=72 

B does seem to be the best answer or am i reading this incorect

comments.content: The command is Match. So B ?

discussion.content:
A centralized data policy based on source and destination prefixes and on headers in IP packets consists of a series of numbered (ordered)
sequences of match-action pair that are evaluated in order, from lowest sequence number to highest sequence number. When a packet
matches one of the match conditions, the associated action is taken and policy evaluation on that packets stops. Keep this in mind as you
design your policies to ensure that the desired actions are taken on the items subject to policy.
"match-action" Meaning ? Action or match ? LOL
I think its B. Because match is always come first after sequence sequence > match > action > default action

answer = B
Look here under "Data Policy Structure" . Page 72
https://www.ciscolive.com/c/dam/r/ciscolive/us/docs/2020/pdf/DGTL-BRKRST-2791.pdf#page=72
i will choose b
I would choose B. Capturing is not an action type and here it means, in my opinion, packets that are interesting for the use case.
B or C?

choices.D: policy > data-policy > vpn-list > sequence > default-action > drop
choices.A: policy > data-policy > vpn-list > sequence > default-action > accept
